0.user_question: Helena is a mad scientist testing her latest creation, the Lots-of-Limbs Serum. The serum will make the drinker grow an extra arm every three days and an extra leg every five days. After fifteen days, how many new limbs will Helena’s serum cause a person to grow if they drink it?

Total Number of Arms= 5

subanswer.text: This question requires finding out when multiplications meet (in this case we need multiples of three and five). To solve it use least common multiple(LCM) calculation; which involves prime factorization method or direct division approach if you know them well enough. Here I’ll go through the divisibility route as follows : Firstly find numbers up until their max limit whose only factors are either themselves or one i.e primes . Prime numbers till twenty are {2 , 3 , 5 , 7 , 11 , 13 , 17 , 19}. Continue writing multiplication pairs along vertical axes into grid layout ; multiply column entries horizontally & check off those results appearing within range constraints.. direct_answer.text:
To solve this problem, we need to determine both when new limbs grow based on condition 2 (every third day) and condition 3 (every fifth day). Let us consider these growth periods separately first:

For growing arms:
Day 3 would see our person acquiring their second hand because it’s divisible evenly into 3 (i.e., Day 1 -> hands: zero; Day 2->hands:one ; Day 3->hands:two). This pattern repeats itself throughout all subsequent multiples of three up until twenty four (the last multiple under or equaling 15), which include Days 3, 6, 9, 12, and 15. 1.subquestion: How often do you grow new limbs according to condition 2?

subanswer.text: You gain an extra arm every three days. In 15 days, this happens \( \frac{15}{3} = 5 \) times. Thus, over these 15 days, people would add 5 arms (but they already had their natural ones). However, let us consider if no initial hands existed; then simply using the formula n=d/k yields exactly how many events happen – meaning you get \(\lfloor\frac{15}{3}\rfloor\) or 'exactly', therefore only growing 5 pairs of artificially added arms.
